title: A Matter of Italics
content:
Two designers quoted the Middle Age era in the lower case "g":  
1. Jan Van Krimpen with the italics of _Lutetia, Romanée, Haarlemmer, Spectrum_  
2. Eric Gill with the italics of _Perpetua, Golden Cockerel, Joanna, Aries_

.

¶ Do you know who's started this italic "g" trend?

.

PS: I've noticed the medieval "g" in the italics of _ITC Galliard_ and _ITC Esprit_.
author: Fournier

comments.content:
¶ What do you imply? Please elaborate.

.  
.

_Exoriare aliquis nostris ex ossibus ultor…_

It seems to me that the model for this kind of |g| (and also for the stemmed |U| which some of your examples also share) is "just" a stylisation of connected cursive handwriting, thus it could well be that there's no one "who's started this italic "g" trend".

It was typical in 1500's Writing Manuals.  
Tagliente, Arrighi, Cataneo, Mercator, Palatinus, Yciar, Vespasiano, Cresci, etc.

¶ You're right. I double-checked chancery typefaces like ITC Zapf Chancery Italic, Poetica, Le Griffe.  
¶ I'm sure it's older than The Renaissance.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140702075042im_/http:/typophile.com/files/zapf_chancery_4584.gif)

> ¶ I'm sure it's older than The Renaissance.

[_Of course_.](http://web.archive.org/web/20140702075042/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/gotisch/fonts/?testdrive=seed%3D22%26size%3D72%26text%3DHandgloves%26fg%3D000000%26bg%3Dffffff%26src%3Dcustom%26goodies%3Dot.liga%26browser%255B%255D%26_2x%3D0)

¶ Designer Eric Gill also fashioned a roman typeface entitled _Jubilee_ (1935) with that "g" and its closed loop.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140702075042im_/http:/typophile.com/files/jubilee_6253.gif)
And this _g_ comes from Gill’s Facia Italic: ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140702075042im_/http:/cdn.myfonts.net/114/fs/u/01/d1f893a4afa32d47d3e21d54a7b7d2.gif)

Find the blackletter FF Ophelia with the closed "g".

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140702075042im_/http:/typophile.com/files/ffophelia_4951.gif)

And Cresci Rotunda.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140702075042im_/http:/typophile.com/files/crescirotunda_4510.gif)

It seems that even the insular style (known for its s-shaped |g|) allows a closed bottom loop: [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/glc/799-insular/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140702075042/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/glc/799-insular/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/glc/799-insular/")

Bree has it in a Roman sans.  
 [http://www.type-together.com/Bree](http://web.archive.org/web/20140702075042/http:/www.type-together.com/Bree "http://www.type-together.com/Bree")
